awd_titl_txt: Conference on Econometrics and Mathematical Economics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds a series of workshops held each year around the country.  These workshops bring together leading scholars as well as junior scientists who are working on cutting edge problems in mathematical economics and on new statistical techniques for the analysis of economic data. The specific workshop topics are Bayesian Inference, Time Series, Forecasting, Microeconometrics, Decentralization, and General Equilbrium.  Each workshop meets once per year, with a particular focus on younger scholars and scholars who have not previously presented in this workshop series.

The conference series makes special efforts to promote learning by young scholars.  Because each workshop meets at a different location each year, students at a wide variety of host institutions and neighboring institutions are able to attend the workshops at no cost. Other broader impacts include the interdisciplinary importance of new statistical methods for data analysis and research that has led to new insights into regulatory policy, the organization of financial markets, and the evaluation of social and economic policy.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The grant supported conference series in econometrics and economic theory. These conferences are all long-standing and important parts of the intellectual communities they represent. Over the long history of CEME, many fundamental advances in econometrics and economic theory were first presented during these workshops. These workshops have long fostered researchers working in both basic and applied areas of econometrics and economic theory.

Each year a conference was organized in each of the series in econometrics and economic theory: Time Series Econometrics, Young Econometricians Conference, Microeconometrics, Bayesian Inference in Econometrics and Statistics, Decentralization, and Mathematical Economics. Conferences were organized at a variety of different academic institutions and research institutions. Each conference series worked to foster interdisciplinary collaborations and cross-pollination. Participants included economists, statisticians, policy makers, computer scientists, political scientists, and other social scientists from both academic institutions, government, and private industries. Each conference has a long tradition of giving priority to junior scholars, and to fostering interactions between junior and senior scholars. They have all provided important opportunites for junior scholars to receive focused feedback on projects at critical junctures, as well as mentoring and networking opportunities.

Basic research in economic theory and econometrics provides the backbone for economics in academics, policy, and industry. Impacts of this project are as important and diverse as macroeconomic advice and forecasting for governments, theory and econometric methods for technology industry giants such as Google, Microsoft, Amazon and Ebay, school choice problems, and organ donation matching theory and practice.


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Christina Shannon
